questions.text: A 28-year-old intravenous drug abuser presents with a history of pain, fever, cough with blood in sputum, night sweats, weight loss, and swelling in his right hip joint. A cold abscess is suspected near the joint upon further examination and investigations. Which of the following is characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: Rapid destruction of cartilage by proteolytic enzymes
Rarely involves the ends of long bones
Always causes more significant systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spreads through the hematogenous route

 

Explanation:

  • The patient in this scenario is most probably having Tuberculous arthritis with the primary focus being pulmonary TB.
  • Tuberculous arthritis typically occurs due to the hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria from a primary focus, most commonly the lungs.

 

Etiology of Tuberculosis of bone and joints:

  • Most common causative organism: Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Sometimes the causative organism is bovine, it spreads through raw milk and is less common in India.

Predisposing conditions:

Chronic debilitating disorders, diabetes, drug abuse, prolonged corticosteroid medication, AIDS, and conditions with reduced defense mechanisms.

Pathogenesis:

  • Bone and joint tuberculosis are always secondary to the primary focus in the lungs, lymph nodes, and other sites.
  • Mode of spread from the primary focus: Haematogenous or direct extension from a neighboring focus.
  • The sequence in which bone and joint tuberculosis affects different areas: Spine > hip > knee > elbow.
  • Most commonly involves the ends of the long bone. Epiphyseal cartilage is not a barrier to invasion. Therefore, the infection reaches the joint sooner. (Option B)
  • Infection persists as chronic osteomyelitis only in the vertebral bodies, and the greater trochanter of the femur.

 

The natural course of the disease:

Inflammation stage:

  • It causes local bone necrosis, caseation, and demineralization due to hyperemia.
  • Without resistance or treatment, bone cortices erode, leading to sub-periosteal abscesses.
  • Cold abscesses may form and burst, creating sinuses.
  • Pathological fractures can occur in affected bones.
  • Joints:
    • Develop low-grade synovitis, with thickened synovial membranes.
    • Unlike pyogenic arthritis where proteolytic enzymes cause severe early destruction of the articular cartilage, tubercular infection causes slow destruction. Once the synovium is inflamed, it starts destroying the cartilage from the periphery. (Option A)
    • This inflammatory synovium at the periphery of the cartilage is called Pannus.
    • The joint fills with pus, causing lax ligaments and subluxation.
    • Pus and debris may cause cold abscesses and chronic sinuses.

Types of tubercular infection pathology:

  • Proliferative response (common):
    • Characterized by chronic granulomatous inflammation with a lot of fibrosis.
  • Exudative response:
    • Extensive caseation necrosis without much cellular reaction.
    • This results in extensive pus formation.

Healing stage:

  • Heals by fibrosis, often leading to fibrous ankylosis, with bony ankylosis common in the spine.
  • Joint space is completely lost in case of severe destruction of articular cartilage.

 

Clinical features:

  • History of previous infection or recent contact with tuberculosis.
  • Common in a child or young adult.
  • Pain and swelling in superficial joints.
  • Synovial thickening.
  • Paraspinal muscle spasm.
  • Muscle wasting
  • Movements are limited in all directions.
  • Cautious gait
  • Military attitude due to spine involvement (Erect spine)
  • In advanced cases of tuberculous arthritis, there may be attacks of fever, night sweats, fatigue, and loss of weight. (Option C)
  • Night cries: the joint, splinted by muscle spasms during waking hours, relaxes with sleep and the inflamed or damaged tissues are stretched or compressed, causing sudden episodes of intense pain.
  • Enlarged and tender regional lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the orthopedic OPD with a four-month history of left knee pain, which worsens with activity and at night. She has had episodes of low-grade fever and fatigue but denies any recent trauma. Upon physical examination, the left knee has limited range of motion and noticeable soft-tissue swelling. An image of the X-ray of the left knee joint is shown below. What is Phemister’s triad, and how does it relate to this case?

choices.text: A triad of symptoms indicating septic arthritis
A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis
A set of criteria for diagnosing osteosarcoma
A triad of radiological criteria for diagnosing Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis

 

Explanation: Phemister’s triad of juxta-articular osteopenia/osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and joint space narrowing suggests tuberculous arthritis but is nonspecific.

X-ray findings:

  • Characteristic signs are soft-tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis.
  • Bone ends appear ‘washed-out,’ and the articular space narrows.
  • In children, epiphyses may enlarge due to prolonged hyperemia.
  • Subarticular bone erosion occurs on both sides, indicating synovial inflammation.
  • Cystic lesions may appear in adjacent bone ends.
  • Little to no periosteal reaction, unlike a pyogenic infection, where reactive periosteal new bone formation is an important feature.
  • Phemister’s triad of juxta-articular osteopenia/osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and joint space narrowing suggests tuberculous arthritis but is nonspecific. (Option B)

 

A triad of symptoms indicating septic arthritis (Option A): Septic arthritis typically presents with sudden onset of joint pain, swelling, and fever, often with systemic signs of infection. The radiological findings associated with septic arthritis usually include joint effusion, slight subluxation, and periosteal reaction but do not specifically include Phemister’s triad. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

A set of criteria for diagnosing osteosarcoma (Option C): Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically presents with bone pain particularly at night, and swelling, and may have characteristic radiological features like a sunburst pattern or Codman's triangle. However, it is not related to Phemister’s triad. Thus, this option is incorrect.

A triad of radiological criteria for diagnosing Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Option D): It is a chronic inflammatory condition in children that can present with joint pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms like fever. The radiological findings are synovial thickening, joint effusion, cartilage loss, and bone erosions. Phemister’s triad is not a feature of JIA. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with right hip drug-susceptible TB has been treated with first-line anti-tubercular drugs (HRZE) for two months. She no longer has fever, and night sweats. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue therapy if symptoms have improved
Continue Isoniazid and Rifampicin for four months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Continue Isoniazid and Rifampicin for four months

 

Explanation:

  • The standard treatment regimen for drug-susceptible skeletal TB involves an intensive phase of four drugs (Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol) for two months, followed by a continuation phase of Isoniazid and Rifampicin for at least four more months (totaling six months of therapy).
  • Since the patient is showing improvement, the next step is to transition to the continuation phase with Isoniazid and Rifampicin for the remaining four months.

 

Medical treatment of Skeletal T.B:

  • 1st line therapy (HRZES)

Regimen:

  • Musculoskeletal TB falls under category I of the WHO treatment category
  • Category I treatment: 2 months of HRZE followed by 4 months of HR (Option A)

Transition to second-line drugs (Option B): Second-line drugs are reserved for cases of drug-resistant TB or when patients are intolerant to first-line therapy. There is no indication of drug resistance or adverse effects in this patient. Therefore, switching to second-line drugs is unnecessary and would increase the risk of side effects. This option is also incorrect.

Start surgical intervention (Option D): Surgery is not the first line of management for skeletal TB unless there is severe joint destruction, neurological complications, or failure to respond to medical therapy. In this case, the patient is responding well to medication, so surgical intervention is not indicated at this stage. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a three-month history of progressively worsening lower back pain, night sweats, and weight loss. There is no history of trauma. On spinal examination, there is significant tenderness over the thoracolumbar spine, gibbus with limited range of motion. Imaging reveals vertebral destruction and a paravertebral cold abscess. Blood tests show an elevated ESR and CRP. Which of the following factors makes the vertebral body particularly susceptible to the spread of tuberculosis bacteria?

choices.text: Via the lymphatic vessels surrounding the spine
Through the Batson's paravertebral venous plexus
By direct extension from the intervertebral discs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Through the Batson's paravertebral venous plexus

Explanation:

  • The vertebral body is more susceptible due to the blood supply of the spine.
  • Embryologically: The lower half of the upper vertebrae, intervertebral disc, and upper half of the lower vertebrae have a common origin from a sclerotome which has its own blood supply, making this area susceptible to tuberculosis bacteria infection via a hematogenous route through Batson's venous plexus.

 

Spinal Tuberculosis:

  • Also known as Pott's Spine.
  • The most common site of skeletal TB is the Spine.
  • In the spine, the thoracolumbar region is mostly affected.

 

Pathology:

 

  • TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route from the primary focus. (Option A)
  • It spreads via the para-vertebral plexus of veins i.e., Batson's plexus, which has free communication with the visceral plexus of the abdomen.
  • Batson's paravertebral venous plexus (Internal vertebral venous plexus) is a valveless plexus that spreads infection to the vertebral body. 
  • Rich vascular plexus in the subchondral region of each vertebrae makes it easier for TB bacteria to spread to the paradisiacal area.

  • Granulomatous inflammation erodes the vertebral margins.
  • This leads to disc degeneration and eventual destruction.
  • Weakening of vertebral trabeculae causes vertebral collapse.
  • Healing:
    • Lytic areas in the bone are replaced by new bone.
    • The adjacent vertebrae undergo fusion by bony bridges, which are permanent.

  • Clinical manifestations:

  • The usual clinical symptom is a painful stiff back, and radicular pain if the nerve root is compressed.

By direct extension from the intervertebral discs (Option C): Intervertebral discs can be affected by TB, but the infection typically spreads to the vertebral body first via blood vessels, not directly from the discs.

Through direct pulmonary tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculosis often originates in the lungs and can spread to the spine, but this option is less specific regarding the route of spread to the vertebral body. The hematogenous spread via Batson's plexus is a more direct explanation for how the infection seeds in the vertebral body. This option is incorrect.

  • Systemic symptoms like loss of appetite, and fever may or may not be present.
  • Cold abscess:
    • Pus and tubercular debris from a diseased vertebra.
    • Called "cold" due to lack of typical inflammation signs (heat, redness).
    • Pus can spread in any direction from the affected vertebra.
  • Classical night cries.
  • Early deformity to occur is loss of normal cervical and lumbar lordosis (due to paraspinal muscle spasm).
  • GIBBUS is commonly seen in the thoracic spine TB.
  • Paraplegia.

questions.text: Which imaging modality is considered the best for assessing vertebral body destruction and sequestrum formation in Pott’s spine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CT scan

 

Explanation: A CT scan is the most preferred imaging modality for the assessment of destruction of the vertebral body and sequestrum formation. They can clearly show the extent of bony changes.


 

X-ray:

  • Reduction of disc space- Lateral X-ray is better for the evaluation of disc space. (Option A)
  • In the early stages- wedging of the vertebrae.
  • In late stages- angular kyphotic deformity.
  • Evidence of cold abscess:
    • Bird nest appearance of cold abscess of the thoracic region showing typical fusiform shape.
  • Rarefaction: There is diffuse rarefaction of the vertebrae above and below the lesion.
  • Types of lesions in the vertebral column are:
    • Paradiscal (most common)
    • Central
    • Anterior
    • Posterior ( pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process)
  • Signs of healing:
    • Sclerosis
    • Sclerotic bone
    • Bony fusion

Image: AP and Lateral view of Lumbosacral spine with diminished intervertebral disc space and erosion of inferior and superior end plate of L4-L5vertebra.

 

CT scan: (Option C)

  • The most preferred imaging modality for the assessment of destruction of the vertebral body and sequestrum formation.
  • The pattern of bone damage, including fragmentary, osteolytic, sclerotic, and subperiosteal changes, is clearly visible on CT scans.

 

MRI: (Option B)

 

  • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
  • IOC for potts spine and potts paraplegia.
  • But doesn't help to visualize bony vertebral destruction.
  • Earlier signs, spinal nerve root, and paraspinal soft tissue are better visualized.
  • The best diagnostic modality for spinal TB.

 

Ultrasound (Option D): It can be used to assess soft tissue structures, fluid collections, and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration or biopsy for early histopathological diagnosis, but is not commonly utilized for evaluating bony structures or deep vertebral lesions. Therefore, it is not suitable for assessing vertebral body destruction in Pott’s spine.

questions.text: Which of the following options would be considered an indication for surgical intervention in Pott’s spine?

choices.text: Worsening neural complications despite conservative treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation: All of them are indications for surgical intervention in cases of Pott's spine.

 

Management

 

  • Chemotherapy (Anti-tubercular treatment) should be continued for at least 9-12 months.
  • Providing rest to the spine during the acute phase, followed by guarded mobilization.
  • Braces (Taylor brace) and rest during the acute phase, followed by guarded movements.

 

Indications for surgery in patients without neurological complications

Indications for surgery in patients with neurological complications
  • Progressive bone destruction despite ATT
  • Failure to respond to conservative therapy
  • Paravertebral abscess when it has increased in size despite medical treatment
  • Spinal instability caused by destruction or collapse, destruction of two or more vertebrae, kyphosis
  • Prevention of severe kyphosis in young children with extensive dorsal lesions
  • Large paraspinal abscess
  • New or worsening neural complications or lack of improvement with conservative treatment
  • Paraplegia of rapid onset or severe paraplegia
  • Late-onset paraplegia
  • Neural arch disease
  • Painful paraplegia in elderly patients
  • Spinal tumor syndrome (epidural spinal tuberculoma without osseous involvement)


 

Surgical procedures:

  • Costo-transversectomy
  • Anterolateral decompression
  • HONGKONG procedure: Anterior decompression and spinal fusion
  • Laminectomy

 

Middle path regimen in managing Pott’s spine:

Regimen: Medical management in all patients + surgical management in the following situations:

  • Lack of response to chemotherapy
  • Recurrent disease
  • Severe neurological weakness
  • Static or progressive neuro deficit despite a course of ATT
  • Deformity
  • Debilitating pain
  • Instability

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with complaints of hip pain that has been progressively worsening over the last six months. She has had a noticeable loss of appetite, weight loss, and night sweats during this time. On examination, she exhibits an antalgic gait, and the X-ray image is shown below. Which stage of this condition does this patient most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stage IV


 

Explanation:

  • This case points to a diagnosis of tuberculosis of the hip (TB hip).
  • Chronic hip pain, loss of appetite, and antalgic gait are classic indicators of a serious underlying condition like TB
  • Site of TB infection at the hip: Acetabulum > Femur
  • The presence of a wandering acetabulum on X-ray is consistent with Stage IV of the following classification:

 

Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification

Stage

Clinical Findings

X-ray findings

Stage I: Synovitis

(Option A)
  • Irritable hip
  • Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation)
  • Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis)
  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

 

Stage II: Early Arthritis

(Option B)
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  •  
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis

(Option C)
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation

/severe arthritis

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.

 

  • End stage of TB hip/arthritis: Fibrous ankylosis
  • End stage of TB spine: Bony ankylosis

 

Note:

Causes of FADIR deformity of the hip:

  • TB HIP
  • Femoroacetabular impingement syndrome

Otherwise, all other hip pathology has FABER.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with very advanced tuberculosis of the hip. He is a manual laborer and expresses a strong desire to maintain his ability to squat, which is important for his daily activities and cultural practices. Which treatment option would be best for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Girdle Stone's Excision

 

Explanation:

  • Girdlestone arthroplasty allows for the removal of diseased tissue
  • Preserve some mobility in a severely damaged hip joint. The postoperative skeletal traction aids in stabilization and promotes healing.
  • This procedure is particularly beneficial for patients who need to maintain functional mobility, such as the ability to squat.

 

Treatment

 

Stage of Synovitis
  • ATT
  • Traction
    • Relieves muscle spasm
    • Gives rest to joint
    • Prevents deformity
    • Maintains joint space
  • Rest and mobilization exercises (Option D)

 

Stage of Arthritis
  • ATT
  • Non weight bearing ROM exercises.
  • If unresponsive, then
    • Synovectomy (Removal of synovium) (Option C)
    • Joint debridement

Stage of Pathological Dislocation
  • Girdle stone's Excision Arthroplasty (Option B)
    • Provide a painless, mobile but unstable joint
    • Hip becomes unstable and the limb short
    • Patient will be able to squat on the floor
    • Preferred in countries where squatting is important(e.g. India)
 
  • Total hip replacement
    • A more costly option but provides stability and functionality. (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of the triple deformity in tuberculosis of the knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lateral displacement of the patella

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral displacement of the patella is not a typical feature of the triple deformity; the primary features involve changes in the tibia and knee flexion rather than patellar positioning.

 

TB knee stages

 

1. Synovitis
  • Boggy swelling

2. Early Arthritis
  • Severe pain and swelling.

3. Late Arthritis/Pathological dislocation
  • Triple deformity (Options A, C, and D)
    • Posterior subluxation of the tibia (due to laxity of the capsule)
    • External or lateral rotation of the tibia (due to spasm of the iliotibial band)
    • Flexion of the knee (due to spasms of the hamstrings)

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with a painless, progressive swelling of the middle phalanx of her left index finger for 3 months. Physical examination reveals a firm, fusiform swelling with restricted movement. X-rays show a cystic lesion in the phalanx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tubercular dactylitis

 

Explanation:

  • Tubercular dactylitis commonly presents as a painless, progressive swelling of the phalanges in young children
  • With radiographic findings of cystic lesions and cortical thinning.
  • The absence of pain and systemic symptoms, combined with the characteristic "spina ventosa" appearance, supports the diagnosis.

TB dactylitis
  • Also called spina ventosa- Painless spindle-shaped fingers
  • Dactylitis is the inflammation of phalanges and metacarpals
  • Dactylitis is primarily caused by TB
  • Syphilis can also cause Dactylitis

 

BCG osteomyelitis
  • Develops when intradermal BCG vaccine hits the bone

Poncet's Arthritis
  • It is tuberculous polyarthritis resembling rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Usually, large joints are involved in skeletal TB (Spine, hip, knee)
  • But in this case, small joints are involved as that of rheumatoid arthritis.

TB Shoulder
  • The common variety is the dry type and is called caries sicca
  • There is no effusion into the joint (non-exudative)

 

Acute Osteomyelitis (Option A): Typically presents with acute pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms like fever. The swelling would be tender, hot, and associated with significant discomfort, which is not the case here. This option is incorrect.

 

Gout (Option B): Presents with sudden, severe pain, often in the big toe. The patient's painless swelling and location (finger) are not consistent with gout. This option is incorrect.



 

Enchondroma (Option D):

  • This benign tumor often presents with asymptomatic lesions but typically doesn't cause spindle-shaped swelling (spina ventosa).
  • X-ray findings would also differ (well-defined, lucent, central medullary lesions). This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A known healed case of TB spine presents with lower limb neurological symptoms with bowel and bladder involvement. What can be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Angular kyphosis

 

Explanation:

Pott's disease with neurological manifestation is called Pott’s paraplegia. In a healed TB case, kyphosis is a common long-term complication due to the destruction of vertebral bodies leading to compression of the spinal cord or nerve roots in the thoracic or lumbar region, causing neurological symptoms in the lower limbs and bowel and bladder.

 

Pott’s paraplegia: (TB Spine with Neurological Involvement)

Early-onset paraplegia Etiology

Inflammatory causes
  • Abscess – commonest (Option B)
  • Granulation tissue (Option A)
  • Circumscribed tuberculous focus
  • Posterior spinal disease
  • Infective thrombosis of the spinal blood supply (Option D)

Mechanical causes
  • Sequestrum in the canal
  • Infected degenerated disc in the canal
  • Pathological dislocation - a ridge of bone pressing on the cord

Late-onset paraplegia Etiology

Causes
  • Recurrence of the disease
  • Prominent anterior wall of the spinal canal in case of severe kyphosis (Internal gibbus)
  • Angular kyphosis
  • Fibrous septae following healing

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • Back Pain
  • Paraparesis (partial paralysis) and then complete paraplegia due to spinal cord compression
  • Sensory loss below the level of spinal involvement
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction, especially in later stages
  • Kyphosis
    • Gibbus deformity is common due to vertebral collapse
    • Angular kyphosis
  • Neurological symptoms can be acute, subacute, or chronic
  • Subacute or chronic forms are more typical, with gradual worsening over weeks to months
  • Vertebral collapse or abscess can cause acute neurological symptoms.
  • The thoracic spine is the most commonly involved

 

Investigations:

  • MRI- investigation of choice
  • CT- to better visualize the vertebral canal

 

Treatment:

Conservative therapy:

  • ATT is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Absolute rest - sling traction for the cervical spine, and bed rest for the dorso lumbar spine.
  • Followed by guarded mobilization.

Surgical therapy:

  • Indication:
    • No improvement in paraplegia
    • Worsening of symptoms
